analyzed: yathā ayam sthāṇuḥ vā puruṣaḥ vā iti

original: tathā imau sthāṇū vā puruṣau vā /

analyzed: yaḥ tu dvayoḥ anyatarasya cora tve siddhe ayam coraḥ ayam vā coraḥ iti saṃdehaḥ

analyzed: sa tu ayam coraḥ na vā iti evaṃrūpa saṃśaya dvaya samāhāraḥ
translated: That is a combination of two doubts in the form Is this one the thief or not?

analyzed: yat vā yaḥ ca uraḥ
translated: Or, the one who is the thief,

original: saḥ ayam ayaṃ vā ityeka eva /
analyzed: saḥ ayam ayam vā iti ekaḥ eva
translated: he is this one or that one - it is only one.

analyzed: atha vā cora tvam etad niṣṭham etad niṣṭham vā iti  yadi api ubhaya vyatirikta puruṣa cora tva abhāvaḥ tayoḥ anyatarasya cora tve vā tātparyāt nirṇaya garbha tvam
translated: Or, the thiefhood belongs to this one or to that one.🔽Even though the absence of thiefhood in a person other than both is included in the determination by the intention that either of them is the thief,

translated: nevertheless, due to the absence of the determination of the difference between either of them, in that part it is only doubt.

analyzed: na ca ekasya api jñānasya saṃśaya nirṇaya ātma tā virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction in a single cognition having the nature of doubt and determination.

analyzed: sarvasmin api saṃśaye nirṇayasya dustyaja tvāt
translated: Because even in all doubt, the determination regarding the property-possessor, etc. is difficult to abandon.

analyzed: punar dvividhaḥ yam anyatara koṭi pariśeṣa yogyatva tad ayogyatva bhedāt
translated: Moreover, this doubt is of two kinds, due to the difference of being fit or unfit for the remainder of either alternative.

original: pūrvo yathāsthāṇvātmake vastuni sthāṇuḥ puruṣo veti /

translated: The former is like Is it a post or a man in a thing having the nature of a post.

analyzed: uttaraḥ tu palāla kūṭe dviradaḥ giri śikharam vā iti

translated: Or, for one who is completely inactive, sometimes by a second doubt and by error, and by chance, when the object of the present moment comes together, there is the attainment of the desired object.

translated: Some say that there is another kind of cognition called indecision, which has the form Is this tree of such and such a name? etc. That is worthless.🔽Because it has the nature of the desire to know that particular thing, which arises immediately after the doubt about the particular thing such as the name, etc.

analyzed: athavā avacchedaka adarśanāt anavacchinna koṭi viśeṣaḥ saṃśayaḥ eva
translated: Or, doubt is itself the cognition of the particular thing whose aspect is not determined due to the non-perception of the distinguishing feature.

translated: Inference is generally in the form of 'this must be a man', etc., and is the same as the one based on the observation of a predominant quality co-occurring with one part, but without the other parts being insignificant.

translated: If the intention is that 'this must be a man' means 'it is a man', then it falls under perception, inference, etc. as appropriate.

translated: But we will discuss inference, which is a form of reasoning, under inference.

analyzed: trividham pramāṇam pratyakṣa anumāna śabda bhedāt

translated: It has also been stated by the revered Manu: Perception, inference, and the scriptures, along with various traditions,

translated: Thus.

analyzed: sarva abhyupagata pramāṇānām iti ca para abhyupagama mātram dyotayati
translated: And of all accepted means of knowledge merely indicates the acceptance of others.

translated: There, since the opponent accepts six means of knowledge,🔽and the difference among perception, inference, and verbal testimony has been clearly explained in the Vedārthasangraha.

original: yattu mattaḥ smṛtijñārnamapohanaṃ ca ityatra bhāṣyam jñānamindriyaliṅgāgamayogajo vastuniścayaḥ iti /

translated: As for what is stated in the Bhāṣya here: Knowledge is the ascertainment of a thing produced by the senses, inference, and verbal testimony,

analyzed: antarbhāvam ca vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And we will explain its inclusion.

original: evam 'dharmavāṃstvamasi' iti kārtāntikopadeśādau 'tādṛśo 'hamasmi' iti bodhe dharmāderapi pratyakṣatvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: evam dharmavān tvam asi iti kārtāntika upadeśa ādau tādṛśaḥ ham asmi iti bodhe dharma ādeḥ api pratyakṣa tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: then in the case of instructions like You possess dharma by a knower of the end, when there is the cognition I am like that, it would follow that dharma etc. are also directly perceived.

analyzed: tatas ca apratyakṣam iti jagati kiñcid na syāt
translated: And then nothing in the world would be non-directly perceived.

original: pratyakṣabhūtaṃ yatkiñciduddiśya viśeṣaṇatayaiva sarvasya pratyakṣatvopapatteḥ /🔽pūrvāvagatadaśamabhāvaṃ tu puruṣaṃ pratyupadeśe bhāṣarāśipraviṣṭamaṣīnyāyena pūrvāparāparokṣaṇīnairantaryeṇa
analyzed: pratyakṣa bhūtam yat kiñcid uddiśya viśeṣaṇa tayā eva sarvasya pratyakṣa tva upapatteḥ  pūrva avagata daśama bhāvam tu puruṣam pratyupadeśe bhāṣa rāśi praviṣṭa maṣī nyāyena pūrva apara apara ukṣaṇī nairantaryeṇa
translated: Because the direct perception of everything is possible only by specifying something that is directly perceived.

analyzed: madhya varti śabda janya dhiyā parokṣa tva vyavahāraḥ kasyacid syāt vā na vā
translated: But in the case of an instruction regarding a person who has previously understood the tenth state, by the method of the black cow entering the herd, the cognition produced by the intervening words may or may not be the usage of non-manifestation for someone.

analyzed: atas eva tattvam asi ādi śabdaḥ sva viṣaya gocara pratyakṣa jñāna janakaḥ
translated: For this very reason, the words That art thou etc. produce the direct knowledge whose domain is their own object.

original: svato 'parokṣārthagocaratvāt daśamastvamasi saṃvit svaprakāśā ityādivākyavat ityādyanumānāni nirastāni /
analyzed: parokṣa artha gocara tvāt daśamaḥ tvam asi saṃvid sva prakāśā ityādi vākya vat ityādi anumānāni nirastāni
translated: Because they themselves have the domain of non-manifest objects, like the sentences You are the tenth consciousness, self-luminous etc. - such inferences are refuted.

analyzed: daśama tva sva prakāśa tva ādi viśiṣṭa ākāreṇa dṛṣṭānteṣu aparokṣa jñāna janana asiddheḥ
translated: Because in the examples, the production of non-manifest knowledge by the form qualified by the tenth state, self-luminosity etc. is not established.

analyzed: tathā vigītaḥ śabdaḥ na sva vācya gocara pratyakṣa dhī janakaḥ
translated: Similarly, a well-known word does not generate a direct cognition that is related to its own meaning.

analyzed: śabda tvāt
translated: Because it is a word.

analyzed: saṃpratipanna vat
translated: Like what is commonly accepted.

analyzed: ityādi api pratiprayoktavyam
translated: This and other arguments should be employed.

analyzed: upalambha virodha śābda pratyakṣa lakṣaṇa saṃkara ādi prasaṅgaḥ tra vipakṣe bādhakaḥ
translated: The logical fallacy of contradiction with perception, and the logical fallacy of mixing the definition of verbal perception, etc., are the reasons that refute the opponent's position here.

analyzed: na evam pūrvasya
translated: The previous [argument] is not like this.

original: śabdajanyapratyakṣamantareṇāpi yogajādṛṣṭajanitasākṣātkārāt praṇidhānaviśeṣaprasāditaparamātmasaṃkalpādvā niḥśreyasasiddheriti //🔽pratyakṣaṃ cidacinmayaṃ jagadidaṃ yasyetyanuśrūyate yaścānanyadhiyāmanantavibhavaḥ pratyakṣatāmaśnute /
analyzed: śabda janya pratyakṣam antareṇa api yogaja adṛṣṭa janita sākṣātkārāt praṇidhāna viśeṣa prasādita paramātma saṃkalpāt vā niḥśreyasa siddheḥ iti  pratyakṣam cit acit mayam jagat idam yasya iti anuśrūyate yaḥ ca an anya dhiyām ananta vibhavaḥ pratyakṣa tām aśnute
translated: Because even without verbal perception, the attainment of liberation is possible through the direct realization produced by yoga, unseen [forces], or the will of the supreme self, which is pleased by special meditation.🔽We wish to see that wise one who is skilled in the method of granting liberation, who is said to be the one in whom this world of consciousness and non-consciousness is perceived, and who, of those who think of nothing else, attains direct perception of infinite glory,

original: yaścaiko yugapatsadā svata idaṃ viśvaṃ darīdṛśyate prājñaṃ taṃ pratipannamokṣaṇavidhādakṣaṃ didṛkṣemahi //
analyzed: yaḥ ca ekaḥ yugapad sadā svatas idam viśvam darīdṛśyate prājñam tam pratipanna mokṣaṇa vidhā dakṣam didṛkṣemahi
translated: and who, alone, is always seen by himself simultaneously as this entire universe.

original: iti śrīkavitārkikasiṃhasya sarvatantrasvatantrasya śrīmadveṅkaṭanāthasya vedāntācāryasya kṛtiṣu nyāyapariśuddhau pratyakṣādhyāye dvitīyamāhnikam
analyzed: iti śrī kavi tārkikasiṃhasya sarva tantra svatantrasya śrīmat veṅkaṭanāthasya vedānta ācāryasya kṛtiṣu nyāya pariśuddhau pratyakṣa adhyāye dvitīyam āhnikam
translated: This is the second section of the chapter on perception in the Nyāyapariśuddhi composed by the venerable Vedāntācārya Veṅkaṭanātha, the independent master of all scriptures and the lion among poets and logicians.

analyzed: samāptaḥ ca pratyakṣa adhyāyaḥ
translated: And the chapter on perception is completed.

analyzed: śrīmate nigama anta mahā deśikāya namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the illustrious great preceptor Nigamanta.
